    BooleanExpression<T extends Bean>
    Class used to hold (and contain) a boolean operation. This class should be overriden and the "execute" method implemented. The execute method is called with a new restriction. All operations on that expression will operate in terms of the condition this expression was passed in to. For example: xxx.or(new BooleanExpression() { public void execute(Restriction restriction) { restriction.compare("A", Equals, 10); restriction.compare("A", Equals, 20); restriction.compare("A", Equals, 30); } }); Will find all things that have (A=10 or A=20 or A=30)

    IQuery<T extends Bean>
    Used to create a new query to the database. The provided bean type is used as the result type.
    IQueryBeanResult<T extends Bean>
    A IQueryBeanResult represents a result from a database query. IQueryBeanResult objects are materialized from a Query object. The Query is strictly a server side entity, so this implies that query results can only be materialized on in the server.

    A query result is the result representation of a query in that it will retrieve results based on the query it was materialized from. While the query represents what underlying data is returned, the query result determines the actual fields that will be fetched. These fields can be specified with the functions retrieveResultsAsColumns and retrieveResultsAsBeans.

    The ordering of the results are specified by the order by columns. Multiple order by columns are specified using the setOrderByColumns function. Sorting can occur whether or not this QueryProcessor is a chuncking query result or all of its results are fetched at once.

    Chunking can be enabled on the QueryProcessor object. Chuncking allows the developer to fetch a subset of the data at any given time. Chunking is a method to prevent unbounded memory consumption by the query layer.

    Results are retuned from a QueryProcessor through the iterator methods.

    QueryBeanResultWithSummary<QT extends Bean,RT extends Object>
    Wraps a {@link IQueryBeanResult} containing search results together with and a {@link IQueryBeanResult} that produces the summary query row for those results. The constructor is parameterized with both the main query results and the summary query results.

    QueryColumnRuntime
    QueryHint
    Adds a hint to a query. Note that a hint may not be used if it is added to the wrong containing object, e.g. an AfterSelect hint will not apply if added to the Table object returned by a join because there's no select because of the join. An AfterSelect hint will apply to a subselect, e.g. ... IN (SELECT ...). SQL Server: http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/ms187713.aspx - 3 places - Query: after the entire query string. - Join: inside the JOIN keywords. E.g. INNER LOOP JOIN - Table: after the join with the table. E.g. UPDATE MyTable WITH (TABLOCK). E.g. SELECT * FROM Table1 AS t1 INNER JOIN Table2 AS t2 WITH (FORCESEEK) ON t1.T2ID = t2.ID Oracle: http://docs.oracle.com/cd/B12037_01/server.101/b10752/hintsref.htm - Always in comments after the SELECT keyword: /*+ hint1 [text] hint2 [text] ...[[END COMMENT]] DB2: Hints work differently and are not added to the SQL H2: None
    QueryOptimizer
    Allows a DB optimization to be performed on the query before it is sent.

    There are two methods that can be used for optimization, before query and after query. These methods can access the DB to turn on options.
